item.title: Japan Policy Chief Hits Back at US Call for 5% Defense Spending
item.description: Japan should focus on enhancing its defense capabilities, not chasing spending goals, the ruling party’s policy chief said, following Trump administration calls for US allies to target higher military expenditure.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama, Akemi Terukina

media:content.media:description: Itsunori Onodera, newly-appointed defense minister of Japan, arrives at the Prime Minister's official residence in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, Aug. 3, 2017. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is reshuffling his ministers and party officials after a slump in popularity and a humiliating local election defeat. Photographer: Tomohiro Ohsumi/Bloomberg

item.title: Powell Says Higher Inflation Outlook Keeping Fed on Hold for Now
item.description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell had plenty of opportunities Tuesday to tell lawmakers definitively the central bank will cut interest rates soon. He didn’t take any of them.
item.dc:creator: Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: Chairman of the US Federal Reserve Jerome Powell Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: Fed’s Barr Says He Expects Tariffs to Boost Inflation
item.description: Federal Reserve Governor Michael Barr said he anticipates tariffs will drive up inflation and expressed support for a wait-and-see approach to interest-rate adjustments.
item.dc:creator: Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: Michael Barr, vice chair for supervision at the US Federal Reserve, speaks during a Senate Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, May 16, 2024. Martin Gruenberg, the embattled head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., told lawmakers calling for his resignation that he was moving quickly to overhaul the agency's workplace culture after a probe detailed complaints of sexual harassment and discrimination at the agency.

item.title: Paraguay Central Bank Keeps Benchmark Rate Unchanged at 6%
item.description: Paraguay’s central bank kept monetary policy on hold Tuesday, leaving the benchmark rate unchanged at 6%.
item.dc:creator: Ken Parks

media:content.media:description: Motorists navigate traffic in downtown Ciudad del Este, Paraguay, on Saturday, Dec. 2, 2023. Paraguay's central bank accelerated the pace of monetary easing at its last monthly policy meeting, delivering a surprise half-percentage point cut to drop the benchmark interest rate to 7.25%.

item.title: Fed Needs More Clarity on Tariff Impact on Prices, Kashkari Says
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari said the US central bank needs more clarity on how tariffs will impact prices before adjusting policy, even as recent inflation data has been “quite positive.”
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Neel Kashkari, president and chief executive officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, speaks during the Monetary and Banking Conference 2024 at the Palacio Libertad in Buenos Aires, Argentina, on Monday, Oct. 14, 2024. Kashkari said it appears likely that "further modest reductions" in the central bank's benchmark interest rate will be appropriate in the coming quarters.

item.title: Here Are the Key Takeaways From Powell’s Testimony Before House
item.description: Here are the key takeaways from Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell’s testimony before the House Financial Services Committee Tuesday:
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

media:content.media:description: Chairman of the US Federal Reserve Jerome Powell during a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, DC, on June 24. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: BOE QE Decision ‘More Interesting This Year,’ Bailey Says
item.description: The Bank of England’s looming annual decision on reducing its government bond portfolio will be “more interesting this year,” according to Governor Andrew Bailey.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ritchie, Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Governor of the Bank of England Andrew Bailey

item.title: Bailey Echoes BOE Colleague Ramsden’s Dovish View of Jobs Market
item.description: Two senior Bank of England policymakers warned that the labor market is cooling and pay pressures are easing in one of the strongest signs yet that the central bank is on course to cut interest rates again later this summer.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Governor of the Bank of England Andrew Bailey Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

item.title: Powell Says Key Capital Rule Change May Aid Treasuries Market
item.description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said Tuesday that potential changes to a key capital buffer should bolster banks’ roles as intermediaries in the US Treasuries market.
item.dc:creator: Katanga Johnson

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, during a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, June 24, 2025. Powell told lawmakers the central bank is in no rush to lower interest rates as officials wait for more clarity on the economic impact of President Donald Trump’s tariffs.

item.title: Labour Rebels Threaten to Kill Starmer’s UK Welfare Cuts
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer said he would push ahead with controversial cuts to UK disability benefits despite a sizable rebellion brewing within his own Labour Party that threatens to derail the plan.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Lucy White

media:content.media:description: The Houses of Parliament in London. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: French Government Under Pressure as Pension Talks Stumble
item.description: Negotiations over France’s contentious retirement reform ended in deadlock late Monday, raising pressure on the government as some opposition parties called for a no-confidence vote.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

item.title: US Consumer Confidence Drops on Broad Concerns About Economy
item.description: US consumer confidence unexpectedly declined in June, underscoring lingering anxiety about the potential impacts on the economy and job market from higher US import duties.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in Palm Beach, Florida.

item.title: Bank of Thailand Deputy, Banker Vie for Governor Role, Report
item.description: The chief executive of a Thai state lender and a career central banker are in race to become Bank of Thailand’s new governor, according to a report, an appointment keenly watched by investors for clues to future monetary policy trajectory.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Thailand complex in Bangkok.

item.title: ECB’s Lane Says Disinflation Process Is ‘Largely Completed’
item.description: European Central Bank Chief Economist Philip Lane said the process of bringing inflation back to 2% is almost over, despite some pockets of elevated price pressures remaining.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: Chief economist of the ECB Philip Lane

item.title: Hungary Holds Rate as Forecast Points to Stagflation Risk
item.description: Hungary’s central bank kept its key interest rate unchanged for a ninth month, with fresh forecasts pointing to persistent inflation and faltering economic growth. The forint gained against the euro.
item.dc:creator: Zoltan Simon, Marton Kasnyik

item.title: Brazil Central Bank Stresses Plan of High Interest Rate for Longer
item.description: Brazil’s central bank hammered home plans to pause its interest rate hiking cycle in anticipation of the effects on above-target inflation, emphasizing that a great part of the impact is still to come.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck

media:content.media:description: The Central Bank of Brazil headquarters in Brasilia.

item.title: Trump’s Chip Tariff Threat Sparks Pushback From Auto Industry to Tech
item.description: Blowback to President Donald Trump’s idea of tariffs on imported semiconductors is proving to be broad and deep, stretching from auto companies and boat makers to the technology industry and crypto enthusiasts, according to a review of more than 150 public comments on the proposal.
item.dc:creator: Michael Shepard

media:content.media:description: A stacker sorts silicon wafers. Photographer: Kyle Green/Bloomberg

item.title: Canada Inflation Holds at 1.7% in May as Core Pressures Cool
item.description: Canadian consumer prices held steady while core measures eased slightly, likely giving some relief to Bank of Canada policymakers who had raised concerns about hotter underlying inflation prints in recent months.
item.dc:creator: Randy Thanthong-Knight, Erik Hertzberg

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in Toronto.

item.title: Mexico’s Headline Inflation Slows Before Expected Interest Rate Cut
item.description: Mexico’s headline inflation ticked down in early June according to a report published on Tuesday, keeping the option of another interest rate cut on the table at the central bank’s decision later this week.
item.dc:creator: Maya Averbuch

item.title: Morocco Hits Pause on Rate Cuts as Mideast Uncertainty Swirls
item.description: Morocco paused a rare monetary-easing cycle, opting for caution even as a tentative Israel-Iran truce appeared to allay immediate concerns over a potential spike in consumer prices.
item.dc:creator: Souhail Karam

media:content.media:description: Shoppers buy fresh produce at the Sidi Moussa market in Sale, Morocco.

item.title: Powell Says Interest Rates Are Now ‘Modestly’ Restrictive

media:content.media:description: Chairman of the US Federal Reserve Jerome Powell during a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, DC, on June 24.

item.title: Fed’s Hammack Says Policy Could Be on Hold for Quite Some Time
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland President Beth Hammack said that interest rates are only modestly restrictive and that officials may hold borrowing costs steady for some time.
item.dc:creator: Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: Beth Hammack, president and chief executive officer of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, at the Columbus Metropolitan Club in Columbus, Ohio, US, on Wednesday, April 16, 2025. Hammack said there is good reason for officials to hold interest rates at current levels until there is more clarity on how tariffs and other policy changes will affect the economy.

item.title: ECB’s Guindos Says Oil Price Not Derailing Inflation Retreat
item.description: European Central Bank Vice President Luis de Guindos said recent swings in commodities prices due to the war between Israel and Iran don’t change the outlook for inflation in the euro zone.
item.dc:creator: Laura Millan, Daniel Hornak

media:content.media:description: Luis de Guindos Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: India’s RBI Signals Policy Shift With Move to Drain Excess Cash
item.description: India’s central bank announced a plan to withdraw excess short-term cash from the banking system, signaling a shift in its stance after months of fund infusions that helped lower borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Malavika Kaur Makol, Subhadip Sircar, Bhaskar Dutta

media:content.media:description: Signage at the Reserve Bank of India headquarters building in Mumbai. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: UK’s Statistics Agency Hires BOE Official to Lead Overhaul
item.description: The Office for National Statistics has appointed a top Bank of England official to lead an overhaul of its crisis-hit economic statistics.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: James Benford

item.title: UK Food Prices Rise Further as Grocers Battle Costs
item.description: Grocery price inflation rose to the highest in 16 months across British supermarkets, with shoppers turning more to own-label ranges to save pennies.
item.dc:creator: Katie Linsell

media:content.media:description: A customer places shopping bags in her car outside a supermarket in Benfleet.

item.title: China’s Answer to World Bank Doubles Down on Global Ambitions
item.description: I’m Malcolm Scott, international economics editor in Sydney. Today we’re looking at China’s ten year experience as an international development lender. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Malcolm Scott

item.title: Number of US-Bound Container Ships Rises on Pacific Horizon
item.description: The busiest US maritime complex looks to get an increase in container cargo in the next couple weeks as businesses race to stockpile ahead of global tariffs that President Donald Trump has threatened to increase. But whether it’ll be an import wave or merely a ripple is unclear.
item.dc:creator: Laura Curtis

media:content.media:description: Seagulls in front of idle gantry cranes at the Port of Long Beach in Long Beach, California, US, on Monday, May 12, 2025. Recent data showed a slump in trade across the Pacific Ocean, fueling worries that Trump's broad tariff agenda could hit American consumers with higher prices and fewer choices and spur a global downturn. Photographer: Tim Rue/Bloomberg

item.title: NATO Cash Bonanza May Become Europe’s Lost Chance for Growth
item.description: Europe’s plans to unleash trillions of euros in new defense spending will be a huge missed opportunity unless the region can work out how to raise productivity in the process.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio

media:content.media:description: A soldier on patrol ahead of the summit in The Hague, on June 23. Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: BOE’s Greene Warns Rising UK Inflation Could Become Sticky
item.description: Bank of England rate-setter Megan Greene warned second-round effects may keep inflation above 3% for longer but said it should not prevent the central bank from pressing on with gradual interest-rate cuts.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Commuters pass the Bank of England (BOE) in London. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
